Title: "Defining the Grammar for the $select Parameter in Azure Search"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdfThe following EBNF (Extended Backus-Naur Form) defines thegrammar for the $select parameter:An interactive syntax diagram is also available:The $select parameter comes in two forms:1. A single star (*), indicating that all retrievable fields should be returned, or2. A comma-separated list of field paths, identifying which fields should be returned.When using the second form, you may only specify retrievable fields in the list.
If you list a complex field without specifying its subfields explicitly, all retrievablesubfields will be included in the query result set. For example, assume your index has anSyntaxselect_expression ::= '*' | field_path(',' field_path)*field_path ::= identifier('/'identifier)*OData syntax diagram for Azure AI Search７ NoteSee OData expression syntax reference for Azure AI Search for the completeEBNF.
Address field with Street, City, and Country subfields that are all retrievable. If youspecify Address in $select, the query results will include all three subfields.Include the HotelId, HotelName, and Rating top-level fields in the results, and includethe City subfield of Address:odata-filter-exprAn example result might look like this:JSONInclude the HotelName top-level field in the results. Include all subfields of Address. Include the Type and BaseRate subfields of each object in the Rooms collection:odata-filter-exprAn example result might look like this:JSONExamples    $select=HotelId, HotelName, Rating, Address/City{  "HotelId": "1",  "HotelName": "Secret Point Motel",  "Rating": 4,  "Address": {    "City": "New York"  }}    $select=HotelName, Address, Rooms/Type, Rooms/BaseRate{  "HotelName": "Secret Point Motel",  "Rating":
